ORG According to NORP child - welfare legislation , each municipality is responsible for promoting the favourable development of children and young persons by taking , if necessary , supportive or preventive measures ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It may also take a child into care and place him in a foster home , a children ’s home or another suitable institution .

The legislation divides measures of the latter kind into CARDINAL categories : the first concerns " voluntary care " , enabling a parent to place his child into the care of a local authority ; the second provides for " compulsory care " , by establishing machinery whereby a local authority can obtain a court decision or order committing a child to its care . It was recourse to this machinery that was in issue in the present case .

CARDINAL . ORG Decisions concerning the applicants’ children were taken under LAW and under LAW containing Special Provisions on the Care of Young Persons DATE ( lag DATE : CARDINAL med särskilda bestämmelser om vård av unga - " LAW " ) . LAW complements LAW DATE , which deals with voluntary care ; on entering into force on DATE , they together replaced LAW . In general , decisions taken under LAW which were still in force on DATE were considered to be decisions taken under LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG Under section CARDINAL(a ) of LAW , the competent local authority in child - care matters - ORG ( barnavårdsnämnden ) or , in GPE and GPE , ORG - was obliged to intervene ( translation from the NORP ) :

" [ if ] a person , not yet DATE , is maltreated in his home or otherwise treated there in a manner endangering his bodily or mental health , or if his development is jeopardised by the unfitness of his parents or other guardians responsible for his upbringing , or by their inability to raise the child . "

Section CARDINAL(b ) of LAW ( which was not applied in the present case ) provided that the local authority also had to intervene if a minor needed corrective measures because of his criminal , immoral or otherwise asocial behaviour .
CARDINAL . ORG As regards section CARDINAL(a ) , the preparatory work to LAW stated , inter alia , the following ( translation from the NORP ) :

" In the future too , an important reason for intervention must be that a minor is exposed to physical maltreatment . The specific reference to this in the text of the statute seems to some extent to obscure the importance of the fact that children and young persons must also be protected from other kinds of treatment which may be harmful to their bodily or mental health . For this reason , the PERSON instead makes it a prerequisite for intervention that the minor is being maltreated in his home or that he is otherwise treated there in such a way as to endanger his bodily or mental health . This amendment in relation to the law now in force does not aim at bringing about any material change . Reasons for intervention , except for physical maltreatment , may be such as are given as examples in the preparatory work to the legislation now in force : for instance , that a child , who is perhaps being cared for with great tenderness , is all the same continuously exposed to mortal danger owing to his mother ’s mental illness , or that an infant is being cared for by a mother who is suffering from tuberculosis in a contagious state . Further examples may be that the minor is obliged to do work that is unreasonably hard considering his age or his strength , that he does not get enough to eat and is for that reason clearly undernourished , or that his home environment is marked by a considerable lack of hygiene . According to the practice that has been applied hitherto , it should also be possible to intervene in those instances where the parents - perhaps because of their religious convictions - omit to give the child the medical care and treatment that he needs . Among the cases where children are exposed to mental injury or danger may be mentioned the one where parents - with evident symptoms of mental abnormalities or of pathological attitudes - bring up their children in a way , as the committee puts it , that includes a kind of spiritual error and which often in the end causes their personality to develop in an undesirable way . When such upbringing has the result that the child ’s mental health is endangered , it comes under the section now dealt with .

For an intervention under section [ CARDINAL ) ] of LAW to be permitted , there must be a danger of the child ’s becoming a misfit because of his GPE vicious way of life or their negligence or inability to educate the child . The provision in question thus concerns abnormalities in the parents or in their capacity to educate ; it lays down that those abnormalities should be such as to endanger the child ’s social development . Parents and other custodians should be treated on equal terms in this respect . Otherwise only amendments of a formal nature seem to be required . Thus , it is suggested that the words ‘ vicious’ and ‘ negligence’ be replaced by the expression ‘ unsuitability as ORG , which seems more appropriate in this context . Obviously , the scope of this expression is somewhat wider than the one currently in use . Apart from ‘ vicious’ and ‘ negligent’ custodians , it thus also covers those suffering from serious mental abnormalities . There seems to be no reason to object to this enlargement of the field of application of this rule . Society should be entitled to intervene as soon as there is a danger of a young person ’s unfavourable social development owing to shortcomings in the custodian . Since the notion of ‘ misfit’ , as the committee has found , should be excluded from this legislation , the intervention of ORG has instead been made subject to the prerequisite that the development of the young person is in jeopardy . This means that intervention shall take place whenever needed to prevent such abnormalities of behaviour as are indicated under section [ CARDINAL ) ] . It should be pointed out that , just as is the case under the law now in force , an intervention does not require that there have so far been any signs of maladaptation in the young person in question . " ( Reproduced in CARDINAL II - FAC , " Journal for Legislation " - DATE , pp . CARDINAL et seq . )
CARDINAL . ORG Conditions for compulsory care under LAW are set out in LAW , which reads ( translation from the NORP ) :

" Care is to be provided pursuant to this LAW for persons DATE if it may be presumed that the necessary care can not be given to the young person with the consent of the person or persons having custody of him and , in the case of a young person aged DATE or more , with the consent of the young person .
Care is to be provided for a young person if :
CARDINAL . ORG lack of care for him or any other condition in the home entails a danger to his health or development ; or
CARDINAL . ORG the young person is seriously endangering his health or development by abuse of habit - forming agents , criminal behaviour or any other comparable behaviour .
CARDINAL . ORG The following are extracts from the preparatory work to LAW , as reproduced in NJA II CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL et seq . ( translation from the NORP ) .
ORG stated :

" An important point of departure for the reform of the social services is that salient features in the handling of individual cases should be respect for liberty and the right of the individual to decide about his own life . The aim of the social services should be to co - operate with the client as far as possible , in order to make him take part in decisions as to the planning of treatment and make him co - operate actively in carrying it out . The social services should offer help and support , but not take over the individual ’s responsibility for his own life . Personal initiative and responsibility must be made part of care and treatment . In this manner the social services may work more actively in a preventive way , and the opportunity to achieve more long - lasting results will be improved .

This fundamental principle of the new legislation has been laid down in section CARDINAL of the Social Services Bill , which stipulates that the measures taken by ORG in regard to any individual person should be conceived and carried out in co - operation with the person concerned . Consequently , all social services’ opportunities to use coercive measures on adults have been abolished . It is true that , regarding young people and children , the possibility of providing care outside their home contrary to the wishes of the young person or his parents is retained . In this field too , the reform means , however , that the right of the individual to be a party to those decisions that concern his own fate is more strongly stressed . The individual should be able to turn to the social services confidently and ask for help , without risking undesired effects in the form of various coercive measures .

At the same time there is unanimity in considering that in certain cases society must be able to use coercive measures against an individual , whenever this is needed to avoid an immediate risk to somebody ’s life or health . "
The Minister of ORG stated :

" LAW , second paragraph , point CARDINAL , indicates that CARDINAL ground for measures on the part of society is that lack of care for a young person in his home or some other situation in his home constitutes a danger to his health or development . This rule refers to situations where the young person does not receive sufficient care in his home or is exposed to treatment in his home that means there is a danger to his mental or physical health or to his social development . By the word ‘ home’ is to be understood the home of the parents , as well as any other home where the young person is residing permanently . Under this description come , inter alia , cases where the young person is subject to maltreatment in his home . Even a slight degree of maltreatment must be supposed to cause danger to the health or development of the young person . If , in such a case , the parents oppose such measures as ORG may consider necessary to assure the protection of the young person , application of the law may come into focus . In case there has been maltreatment of a more serious kind , the young person should as a matter of course be provided with care outside his home , at least for some time .

As with LAW , this provision may also be applied in those instances where the parents intend to place the young person in an environment that will endanger his health or his development , or where they do not prevent him from being in such an environment .

This section thus embraces all those situations where the child is being exposed to physical maltreatment or negligent care . This legislation may also be applicable if parents endanger the mental health of a child by their personal characteristics . If the child ’s mental health or development is being endangered because of parental behaviour - for instance , by way of continuously recurring scenes at home owing to abuse of alcohol or narcotics - or because of the mental abnormality or state of the parents , it should be possible to provide care for the child under LAW .

The LAW is primarily aimed at enabling the social services to provide for the young person ’s need of care . It is the current need of care , and what can be done at the moment and in the future to see to it that this need is met , that will govern the measures taken by ORG . As I have pointed out in my general statement concerning this PERSON , this legislation can , however , not be used to provide for society ’s need for protection . It is a different matter that , in those instances where a young person needs to be taken into care according to this LAW , this measure will also have the effect of protecting society .

ORG is to take appropriate measures as soon as it considers that a situation such as has been indicated in the second paragraph under points CARDINAL and CARDINAL arises . It may , for instance , have come to the knowledge of the ORG that a child is being exposed to unsuitable treatment or even to actual danger at home . During an inquiry the situation may appear to be such that the child ought to be provided with care outside his home . The ORG should then in the first place try to meet the need for care by reaching an understanding with the parents . In case the parents and the ORG can not reach an agreement as to the question of how the child should be cared for , the ORG must turn to ORG to obtain a decision on care under LAW , with an inherent authorisation permitting the ORG to make decisions regarding the way in which the care should be implemented . "

CARDINAL . ORG was empowered to exercise functions and make decisions in child - welfare matters within a municipality ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) . In doing so , it had to give particular attention to minors who were exposed to the risk of unfavourable development due to their physical and mental health , home and family conditions and other circumstances ( section CARDINAL ) . ORG was composed of lay members who were assisted by social workers .

CARDINAL . ORG Since the DATE social - services legislation entered into force , the functions of ORG have been taken over by ORG , which are composed in the same way as the former ORG but are responsible for social welfare in general .

The tasks of ORG may , as is the case in GPE , be performed by CARDINAL or more ORG , each being responsible for a designated area . In child - care matters , a ORG has the same powers and duties as a ORG .
CARDINAL . ORG As were ORG , ORG are under the supervision and control of ORG and ORG ( socialstyrelsen ) .

CARDINAL . Child Welfare Boards sought and received information about ill - treatment of children or their unsatisfactory living conditions through various officials having frequent contacts with children , such as social workers , doctors , nurses and teachers . Matters of this kind could also be reported to the ORG by private citizens . Upon receipt of such information , a ORG had to undertake , without delay , a comprehensive investigation , including interviews , medical examinations and visits to the child ’s home .

CARDINAL . ORG If ORG found that the child ’s situation corresponded to that described in section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , it had , before resorting to care , to endeavour to remedy the matter by preventive measures ( förebyggande åtgärder ) . These could consist of CARDINAL or more of the following steps : advice , material support , admonition or warning , orders pertaining to the child ’s living conditions , or supervision ( section CARDINAL ) . If such measures proved insufficient or were considered pointless , the ORG had to place the child in care ( section CARDINAL ) .

However , a child had to be taken provisionally into care for investigation ( without the need for prior preventive measures ) if there was a probable cause for intervention under LAW and if there would otherwise be a risk of deterioration in his situation . Such a decision was valid for a maximum period of DATE ( section CARDINAL ) .

In urgent situations where the decision of the ORG LAW or CARDINAL could not be awaited , LAW empowered the Chairman of ORG to take interim action alone . If he did so , he had to convene a meeting of ORG within DATE in order that a decision be taken in the matter .

CARDINAL . ORG Further procedural requirements for placing a child in care under LAW or CARDINAL of the DATE Act were set out in section CARDINAL ; in particular , the decision had to be notified without delay to the parents concerned . If they disagreed , the matter had to be referred for review to ORG within DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW , if a ORG considers that certain action is necessary , it has to apply to ORG for a decision ; unlike ORG under LAW , it can not take the decision itself .
In urgent cases , however , the ORG or its Chairman may place a child in care as a provisional measure ; such a step must be referred within DATE to ORG , for decision within DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG When a care decision has been taken , ORG ( formerly ORG ) has to implement it , by attending to the practical details of such matters as where to place the child and what education and other treatment to give him ( sections CARDINAL and QUANTITY of the DATE Act and sections CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The DATE Act provided that a child who had been taken into care was entitled to good care and upbringing as well as the education that was necessary in the light of his personal capacity and other circumstances . The child had preferably to be placed in a foster home or , if that was not possible , in a suitable institution , such as a children ’s home or school ( sections CARDINAL and DATE ) . ORG had to supervise the care and the development of the child and , if necessary , take decisions concerning his or her personal affairs ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

During the course of the preparatory work to LAW , ORG stressed that it was essential for the development of the child that the parents had regular contacts with him ; this was also of decisive importance so as to ensure that his return to his original home could be effected smoothly . In fact , LAW of the DATE Act provides that he may be allowed , after a period , to return to live there , if it appears that such a course is the best in order to further the aims of the care decision .

CARDINAL . ORG The DATE Act provided that ORG could regulate a parent ’s right of access to his child in care to the extent that it found this reasonable in the light of the aims of the care decision , the upbringing of the child or other circumstances ( section CARDINAL ) .

Under LAW , restrictions on access can be imposed by ORG , in so far as this is necessary for the purposes of the care decision ( section CARDINAL ) . Unlike LAW , LAW expressly empowers the authority concerned to refuse to disclose the child ’s whereabouts .

CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW ) of LAW , compulsory care had to be discontinued as soon as the aims of the care decision had been achieved . The corresponding rule in LAW provides that the ORG shall terminate care when it is no longer necessary ( section CARDINAL , first paragraph ) . The preparatory work to this provision , as reproduced in the ORG ’s PERSON ( DATE , p. CARDINAL ) , stated ( translation from the NORP ) :

" It follows that an important task of the ORG is to see to it that ... care does not continue for longer than is necessary in the circumstances . Care is to be discontinued as soon as there is no longer any need for the special prerogatives granted to the ORG by the LAW . It is true that it is part of the custodian ’s responsibility resting with the ORG to pay close attention to the care provided by other people on the ORG ’s behalf . However , against the background of , inter alia , the way LAW is DATE applied , it has been considered important that the supervisory duties of the ORG are clearly laid down in the text of the [ new ] Act . "

Section CARDINAL of the Social Services Ordinance DATE ( socialtjänst- förordningen CARDINAL ) lays down that a care decision based on unsatisfactory conditions in the child ’s home must be reconsidered by ORG regularly and at least once DATE .

Both before and after the entry into force of LAW , a parent could , under the general principles of NORP administrative law , at any time request that the compulsory care of his child be terminated .
CARDINAL . ORG Decisions of ORG that a child be taken into care might ( under LAW ) or may ( under LAW ) be the subject of an appeal to ORG and , with leave , to ORG .
A parent could or can also appeal to ORG ( and then to ORG and , with leave , to ORG ) against :
( a ) refusals by ORG or ORG to terminate care ordered under the DATE or LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL in fine above ) ;
( b ) decisions taken by ORG under LAW relating , inter alia , to the visiting rights of the parents ;

( c ) decisions taken by ORG under LAW as to where the care should commence ; to change a placement decision ; regulating the GPE right of access ; and not to disclose the child ’s whereabouts to them ( section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ) .

According to the Government , LAW did not entitle a parent to appeal to ORG against a placement decision as such , but LAW does . The Government maintained , however , that the applicants could at any time have raised before ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) - with the possibility of a subsequent appeal to ORG and thence to ORG - a plea that , as a result of their placement and contrary to the requirements of LAW , the children were not receiving proper care and education .
